repnme.cdata!:
Ukraine - The Coal Pilot Project and the
            Coal Sector Adjustment Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcomes of both projects was
            satisfactory and project sustainability for the Pilot
            Project is rated as highly likely, while project
            sustainability for the SECAL is more complex, though the
            sustainability of its benefits was rated as likely. The
            institutional development impact of the Pilot was rated as
            substantial, while that for the SECAL project was only
            modest. World Bank and Borrower performances in both
            projects were rated as satisfactory. Several lessons were
            learned: Quick-disbursing SECALs are inappropriate vehicles
            for supporting sector restructuring programs. SECALs in
            support of mine closures should be designed with several
            small, flexible tranches, rather than a small numberof large
            tranches. Projects designed to support setor restructuring
            should have a clear focus on poverty reduction objectives.
            The financial and economic performance of pilot projects
            activities needs to be carefully monitored. The Bank needs
            to make greater efforts to help improve the eficiency of
            mine closure activities. The Bank should consider working
            more closely with other bilateral and multicultural agencies
            that are providing seed money for establishing local
            cooperatives and other self-help institutions.

1943359.trustfund:
TF028152-SHORT MISSION TO UKRAINE,TF036836-UKRAINE - COAL SECTOR
            ADJUSTMENT PROJECT,TF032697-UKRAINE - POWER SECTOR REFORM
            METERING AND COMMUNICATIONS STUDY,TF033555-UKRAINE - ELECTRICITY REFORM PROJECT,TF033777-UKRAINE - COAL RESTRUCTURING I,TF033331-GEORGIA - HEALTH AND SOCIAL SECTORS,TF021995-PHRD-EMPLOYMENT, SOCIAL
            PROTECTION & SERVICES,TF023664-DUTCH CTF FOR UKRAINE ENERGY,TF029340-PHRD-COAL RESTRUCTURING PROJ.
            PHASE I

abstracts.cdata!:
Project outcome is assessed as
            satisfactory and project sustainability is likely. Both
            World Bank and Borrower performances are overall
            satisfactory. Lessons included the following: The pilot
            operation was very useful in setting in motion a major
            restructuring program--the mere fact that the pilot closure
            was successful was sufficient to trigger an accelerated mine
            closure program and thus substantially reduce the drain on
            the national budget. In deviating from the best practice
            norm, this project had several disbursement conditions for
            different components, allowing fast processing and early
            loan effectiveness, thus enabling the national economy to
            reap the benefits of fast restructuring. Also, when it
            became evident during implementation that micro-credits and
            employment subsidies were ineffective social mitigation
            measures at this time, the funds were shifted to public
            works which, beside the positive temporary employment, had
            added social benefits for the local public, and through the
            goodwill created, contributed to keeping the pace of mine
            closures. Triggered by difficulties met in financing social
            assets transfers and the need to provide incentives for such
            transfers and improve conditions in communities with closed
            mines, the Bank's supervision team, in close
            cooperation with the beneficiaries, developed the Municipal
            Credit Line. Procedures that could improve mine closures
            include sufficient preparation, splitting tasks, and
            tailoring the agency for mine closures.

5082783.trustfund:
TF036836-UKRAINE - COAL SECTOR
            ADJUSTMENT PROJECT,TF028152-SHORT MISSION TO UKRAINE,TF033331-GEORGIA - HEALTH AND SOCIAL SECTORS,TF029340-PHRD-COAL RESTRUCTURING PROJ.
            PHASE I,TF021995-PHRD-EMPLOYMENT, SOCIAL
            PROTECTION & SERVICES,TF033777-UKRAINE - COAL RESTRUCTURING I
5082783.majtheme: Environment and natural resource management,Social protection and risk management,Financial and private sector development

abstracts.cdata!:
The central objective of the Coal Pilot
            Project is to mitigate the social and environmental
            consequences that arise from the government's decision
            to close uneconomic coal mines, as part of government's
            overall restructuring program for the coal sector. The
            project seeks to: 1) test ways to implement the
            government's decision to close mines safely, with due
            regard to technical, environmental, economic, financial and
            social aspects; 2) ensure that mine workers are afforded
            opportunities to either transfer to other jobs in the sector
            or exit the industry with reasonable compensation and a
            choice of assistance for seeking other employment; 3)
            transfer social assets to municipal management, support
            their rationalization and help ensure that adequate social
            protection measures are put in place to support the most
            vulnerable people; and 4) through monitoring and feedback,
            gain experience from the project for subsequent bank
            assistance operations in the sector. The project consists of
            the following five components which will serve as the basic
            framework for mitigation initiatives in subsequent sector
            operations requested by the government: 1) mitigation of
            mine closure including physical closure and environmental
            mitigation; 2) social mitigation; 3) social infrastructure
            divestiture; 4) institutional strengthening and job
            counseling; and 5) technical assistance.
